newsitem.title: USA: US Midwest direct hogs seen off $0.50-$1 - dealers.
newsitem.headline: US Midwest direct hogs seen off $0.50-$1 - dealers.

text.p: U.S. Midwest direct cash hog prices Tuesday were seen $0.50 to $1.00 per cwt lower, pressured by outlooks for increased marketings and light packer demand, livestock dealers said.
Interior Iowa and southern Minnesota hog marketings Monday were estimated at 110,000 head, compared with 108,000 a week ago and 105,000 a year ago, USDA reported.

Marketings on Monday were active enough to provide at least one major packer in the interior Iowa/southern Minnesota area with enough hogs for Tuesday and provide a "good start" on Wednesday supplies, a packer hog buyer said.
Interior Iowa and southern Minnesota top prices for hogs delivered to the plant were seen $0.50 lower at $57.00, livestock dealers said.
Illinois top hog prices at the plant were expected $0.50 lower at $56.00 and Indiana/Ohio top prices at the plant were seen down $1.00 at $56.00.
"We got enough hogs today to fill what light demand we had," one buyer in central Indiana said.
Expectations for increased hog supplies amid light to moderate pork demand also were seen pulling wholesale pork prices lower, the dealers said.

Fresh hams at midday were quoted steady to down $4.00 per cwt, pork bellies were steady to $2.00 higher and lean trimmings were down $1.00 in slow trading, USDA reported in its central U.S. carlot pork report.
There were 15.5 loads of pork cuts and 4.24 loads of trimmed and processed pork sold by midday.
